children.text: Using HTML in srcDoc property
Overview
This app demonstrates - how to use the srcDoc property of an iFrame widget.
How to use this app?
1. Edit the srcDoc property of the iFrame widget. 2. Add a few new HTML elements to the document. 3. Add more styles to the style tag.
How to build this app?

1. Drag an iFrame widget onto the canvas. 2. Fill the srcDoc property of the iFrame widget with HTML. This can be done in a few ways: a. Write your HTML directly into the srcDoc field. b. Write your source doc in an external editor and copy it over. c. Create a JSObject that generates HTML.
Note: Please hover over pointers (1, 2 ..) in the following app, they point to the parts of the app that you should look at to understand how it is built.

children.srcDoc:
Hello World!

  • Veniam excepturi accusantium ratione!
  • Eius veritatis vel exercitationem?

children.onClick: {{postWindowMessage('Hello from Appsmith parent to embedded iframe!','Iframe1', '*')}}
children.text: Send Message to iframe from Appsmith
Send message to parent window

children.srcDoc:
<!doctype html>
<html>

<head>
  <meta charset="UTF-8">
</head>

<body>

	
	<button onclick="sendMsg()">Send message to iframe window</button>

		
  <script>

function sendMsg() {
window.parent.postMessage("hi", "*");
}

window.addEventListener("message", (e) => {
		showAlert(e.data);
		})
		
  </script>

</body>
</html>
children.onMessageReceived: {{showAlert('Message received from iframe entity to iframe window!','info')}}

children.srcDoc:
<!doctype html>
<html>

<head>
  <meta charset="UTF-8">
</head>

<body>

	
	<button onclick="sendMsg()">Send message to iframe window</button>

		
  <script>

function sendMsg() {
window.parent.postMessage("hi", "*");
}

window.addEventListener("message", (e) => {
		showAlert(e.data);
		})
		
  </script>

</body>
</html>
children.onMessageReceived: {{showAlert('Message received from iframe entity to iframe window!','info')}}
